column1: Much of the land was purchased by Roger Williams from the Narragansett Indians in 1638 as part of the Pawtuxet Purchase
column2: and the first settler in the area was William Arnold
column3: who was followed shortly by William Harris
column4: William Carpenter and Zachariah Rhodes. Stephen Arnold
column5: a brother-in-law of Rhodes and William Arnold
column6: built a gristmill on the Pawtuxet falls and laid out the "Arnold Road" (modern-day "Broad Street") connecting it to the Pequot Trail leading to Connecticut. Arnold's son
column8: became the first Governor of Rhode Island under the charter of 1663. After area residents were unable to agree upon a name for a new town for decades
column9: the Town of Cranston was eventually created by the General Assembly in 1754 from a portion of Providence north of the Pawtuxet River. Historians debate whether the town was named after Governor Samuel Cranston
column10: the longest-serving Rhode Island governor or his grandson
column12: who was serving as Speaker of the Rhode Island House of Representatives at the time that the town was created. In the early 1770s town meetings were held at the taverns of Caleb Arnold and Nehemiah Knight where Cranstonians voted in favor of a resolution opposing the British Parliament's Coercive Acts
column13: and the town heavily supported the Patriot cause during the Revolutionary War. After losing much of its territory to neighboring towns and the city of Providence over the nineteenth century
column14: Cranston itself became a city on 10 March 1910.Many Italian-Americans in Cranston are descended from immigrants of Itri
column15: Italy who settled mainly in the Knightsville section of Cranston during the early 1900s. Cranston is known for the St. Mary's Feast
column16: inspired by the Feast of the Madonna della Civita celebrated in Itri. Since 1905
column17: the St. Mary's Feast has been a week-long festival celebrated in July in Cranston with vendors
column20: and a religious procession from St. Mary's Church on Sunday. In 2000
column21: Cranston and Itri became sister cities.

column1: Companies with corporate headquarters in Cranston include jewelry maker Alex and Ani and Coastway Community Bank. The first Del's Lemonade stand was opened in Cranston in 1948.

column1: The Rhode Island Department of Corrections has its headquarters and its adult prison facilities in Cranston. The Rhode Island Department of Children
column2: Youth & Families operates the Rhode Island Training School (RITS)
column4: in Cranston. The Rhode Island Division of Motor Vehicles is headquartered in Cranston.The City of Cranston operates under a mayor-council form of government. General city elections are held on the first Tuesday in November of every even-numbered year. Terms for elected officials begin on the first Monday in January of the year following their election. The City Council consists of nine members: six representing each of the City wards
column5: and three citywide representatives. Council members are elected to a two-year term
column6: and are limited to five consecutive two-year terms. The current Cranston City Council President is Michael Farina and the council has a Republican majority.

column11: Cranston is a part of Rhode Island's 2nd congressional district and is currently represented by Democrat James R. Langevin.

column2: Cranston is reliably Democratic as no Republican presidential nominee has won the city in over three decades.
